results.title: Preston Sturges: the rise and fall of an American dreamer
results.brief_description: This is a survey of the career of writer-director Preston Sturges tracing the highs and lows of his life illuminated with clips from his films and extracts from interviews with Eddie Bracken, Betty Hutton, Joel McCrea, Paul Schrader, Andrew Sarris and others. Sturges is acknowledged as Hollywood’s first ironist whose satires of American mores skillfully outwitted the Hays code. Clips featured are from “The Great McGinty (1940)”, “Sullivan’s travels (1941), “The Miracle of Morgan’s Creek” (1944), “Hail the conquering hero” (1944), “The Beautiful blond from bashful bend” (1949), plus many more. Narrated by Fritz Weaver.

results.title: Pruning practices at the Brooklyn Botanic Gardens
results.creator_credit: Stuart Chasmar and Centre for Mass Communication
results.brief_description: Shows how proper pruning produces healthy plants of good appearance. Demonstrates techniques of pruning deciduous and evergreen trees, roses, rhododendron, forsythia, lilac, hedges etc., and follows the growth of the plants through the year.

results.title: Protestant Christianity
results.brief_description: Protestantism represents the outcome of centuries of disagreement over doctrine and practice within the Catholic Church. Led by Martin Luther in 16th century western Europe, this spiritual revolution gained momentum and, under the helm of other Protestant leaders, thrived and grew into new factions around the world, especially in Europe and North America. Narrated by Ben Kingsley, this video also investigates the numerous denominations that developed over the centuries, including Calvinists, Baptists, Mennonites, Presbyterians, Puritans, Amish and Quakers.

results.title: Inversion (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Jay Hines, Seymour Schuster, College Geometry Project, University of Minnesota and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Geometric inversion is introduced and discussed to effect the solution of an apparently difficult problem involving the inscription of a chain of circles between two given circles, one inside the other. The final result, known as Steiner’s Porism, is forcefully illustrated in motion - “pop art” fashion.

results.title: Regular homotopies in the plane. No. 2 (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: William Hansard and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Uses computer-generated animation in order to illustrate the Whitney-Graustein theorem - two regular curves in the plane are regularly homotopic if, and only if, they have the same rotation number.

results.title: Regular homotopies in the plane. No. 1 (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: William Hansard and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Computer animation records the deformation of regular closed curves and the rotation of tangent vectors and demonstrates the theorem that two regular curves in the plane which are regularly homotopic must have the same rotation number. Concludes with a concrete problem and a challenge to explore the converse of the theorem as discussed in part 2.

results.brief_description: Designed to introduce migrants to aspects of Australian society and provide them with information and language required in specific contexts such as filing a tax return or buying a car.

results.title: Turning a sphere inside out (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: William Hansard, David Nelson and Educational Development Center
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”
Uses advanced computer animation to discuss the problem of turning a sphere inside out by passing the surface through itself without making any holes or creases. Illustrates the homotopy with a sequence of models, showing the crucial stages in the motion.

results.title: Space filling curves (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: William Hansard, Education Development Center and Topology Films Project
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Geometry”.
Using computer animation the concept of a limit curve is graphically portrayed as a sequence of approximate curves and applied to the construction of space filling curves; curves which pass through every point in a square.
results.creator_credit_for_label: William Hansard, Education Development Center and Topology Films Project
